publicationStmt.publisher: Mother Bombie was entered into the Stationers' Register on 18 June 1594, and was published later that year, in a quarto printed by Thomas Scarlet for the bookseller Cuthbert Burby.

sourceDesc.p:
Play details
Mother Bombie. Genre: Comedy. Date first published: 1594. Date first performed: 1587-1590.

encodingDesc.p:
The characters are identified by IDREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Memphio Dromio Stellio Risio Prisius Sperantus Livia Candius Synis Halfpenny Lucio Silena Mother Bombie Vicina Maestius Serena Rixula Nasutus Linceo Accius Bedunenus Sergeant Hackneyman Scrivener Omnes/multiple voices
4.Pag. 1 Fiddler 2 Fiddler 3 Fiddler

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by IDREF which point to the following. Latin

sp.speaker: Memph.
sp.p: Boy there are three things that make my life miserable, a threadbare purse, a cursed Wife, and a Fool to my heir.

sp.speaker: Dromio.
sp.p: Why then sir, there are three medicines, for these three maladies: a pike staff to take a purse on the high way, a holly wand to brush choler from my mistress tongue, and a young Wench for my young master: so that as your Worship being wise begot a Fool, so he being a Fool may tread out a Wise man.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Aye but Dromio, these medicines bite hot on great mischiefs, for so might I have a Rope about my neck, Horns upon my head, and in my house a litter of Fools.

sp.speaker: Dromio.
sp.p: Then sir you had best let some Wise man sit on your son, to hatch him a good wit: they say, if Ravens sit on Hens eggs, the Chickens will be black and so forth.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Why boy, my son is out of the shell, and is grown a pretty Cock.

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: Carve him master and make him a Capon, else all your breed will prove Coxcombs.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: I marvel he is such an Ass, he takes it not of his father.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: He may for anything you know.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Why Villain, dost thou think me a fool?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: O no sir, neither are you sure that you are his Father.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Rascal, dost thou imagine thy Mistress naught of her body?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No, but fantastical of her mind, and it may be, when this boy was begotten she thought of a fool, and so conceived a fool, yourself being very wise, and she surpassing honest.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: It may be, for I have heard of an AEthiopian that thinking of a fair picture, brought forth a fair Lady, and yet no bastard.

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: You are well read sir, your son may be a bastard and yet legitimate, yourself a Cuckold, and yet my Mistress virtuous, all this in conceit.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Come Dromio, it is my grief to have such a son that must inherit my Lands.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: He needs not sir, I will beg him for a fool.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Vile boy, thy young Master?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Let me have in a device.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I will have thy advice, and if it fadge, thou shall eat, thou shall sweat, play till thou sleep, and sleep till thy bones ache.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Aye marry, now you tickle me, I am both hungry, gamesome, and sleepy, and all at once, I will break this head against the wall, but I will make it bleed good matter.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Then this it is, thou knowest I have but one son, and he is a fool.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A monstrous fool.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: A Wife and she an arrant Scold.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ah Master I smell your device, it will be excellent.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Thou canst not know it till I tell it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I see it through your brains, your hair is so thin, and your skull so transparent, I may sooner see it than hear it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Then boy hast thou a quick wit, and I a slow tongue, but what is it?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marry either you would have your Wives tongue in your son's head, that he might be a prating fool, or his brains in her brain pan, that she might be a foolish Scold.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Thou dreamest Dromio, there is no such matter, thou knowest I have kept him close, so that my neighbours think him to be wise, and her to be temperate, because they never heard them speak.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Thou knowest that Stellio hath a good farm and a fair daughter, yea so fair that she is mewed up, and only looketh out at the windows, lest she should by some roisting courtier be stolen away.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Now if I could compass a match between my son and Stellios daughter, by conference of us parents, and without theirs, I should be blessed, he cozened, and thou forever set at liberty.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A singular conceit.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Thus much for my son, now for my wife, I would have this kept from her, else shall I not be able to keep my house from smoke, for let it come to one of her ears, and then woe to both mine: I would have her go to my house into the country whilst we conclude this, and this once done, I care not if her tongue never have done: these if thou canst effect, thou shalt make thy master happy.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Think it done, this noddle shall coin such new device as you shall have your son married by tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: But take heed, that neither the father nor the maid speak to my son, for then his folly will mar all.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Lay all the care on me, Subleuabo teonere, I will rid you of a fool.

sp.speaker: Memphio.
sp.p: Wilt thou rid me for a fool?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Tush quarrel not.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Then for the dowry, let it be at least two hundredth ducats, and after his death the farm.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Then let us in, that I may furnish thee with some better counsel, and my son with better apparel.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Let me alone, I lack but a wag more to make of my counsel, and then you shall see an exquisite cozenage, and the father more fool than the son.
But hear you sir, I forgot one thing.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay, Expellas furca licet vsque recurret.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What is the meaning?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why though your sons folly be thrust up with a pair of horns on a fork, yet being natural, it will have his course.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I pray thee no more, but about it.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Risio my daughter is passing amiable, but very simple.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: You mean a fool sir.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Faith I imply so much.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then I apply it fit: the one she takes of her father, the other of her mother, now you may be sure she is your own.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I have penned her up in a chamber, having only a window to look out, that youths seeing her fair cheeks, may be enamoured before they hear her fond speech. How likest thou this head?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: There is very good workmanship in it, but the matter is but base, if the stuff had been as good as the mold, your daughter had been as wise as she is beautiful.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Dost thou think she took her foolishness of me?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Aye , and so cunningly, that she took it not from you.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Well, Quod natura dedit tollere nemo potest.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: A good evidence to prove the fee-simple of your daughters folly.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: It came by nature, and if none can take it away, it is perpetual.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Nay Riscio, she is no natural fool, but in this consisteth her simplicity, that she thinketh herself subtle in this her rudeness, that she imagines she is courtly, in this the overshooting of herself , that she overweaneth" of herself .

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Well, what follows?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Risio this is my plot, Memphio hath a pretty stripling to his son, whom with cockering he hath made wanton, his girdle must be warmed, the air must not breath on him, he must lie abed till noon, and yet in his bed break his fast, that which I do to conceal the folly of my daughter, that doth he in too much cockering of his son. Now Risio how shall I compass a match between my girl and his boy?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Why with a pair of compasses, and bring them both into the circle, I will warrant they will match themselves.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: Tush, plot it for me, that never speaking one to another, they be in love one with another, I like not solemn wooing, it is for courtiers, let country folks believe others reports as much as their own opinions.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: O then, so it be a match you care not.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Not I, nor for a match neither, were it not I thirst after my neighbours farm.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: A very good nature. Well if by flat wit I bring this to pass, what is my reward?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Whatsoever thou wilt ask.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I will ask no more than by my wit I can get in the bargain.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Then about it.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: If I come not about you never trust me , I will seek out Dromio, the counsellor of my conceit.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: It is unneighbourly done to suffer your son since he came from school, to spend his time in love, and unwisely done to let him hover over my daughter, who hath nothing to her dowry but her needle, and must prove a Sempster, nor he anything to take to but a Grammar, and cannot at the best be but a schoolmaster .

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Prisius, you bite and whine, wring me on the withers, and yet winch your yourself , it is you that go about to match my girl with my boy, she being more fit for seams than for marriage, and he for a rod than a wife.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Her birth requires a better bridegroom than such a groom.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And his bringing up another gate marriage than such a minion.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Marry gup, I am sure he hath no better bread than is made of wheat, nor worn finer cloth than is made of wool, nor learned better manners than are taught in schools.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Nor your minx had no better Grandfather than a Tailor, who as I have heard) was poor and proud: nor a better father than yourself , unless your wife borrowed a better, to make her daughter a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Twit not me with my ancestors, nor my wives honesty, if thou dost.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Hold thy hands still thou hadst best, and yet it is impossible now I remember, for thou hast the palsy.

sp.speaker: Pr.
sp.p: My hands shake, so, that wert thou in place where, I would teach thee to cog.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Nay if thou shake thy hands, I warrant thou canst not teach any to cog. But neighbour, let not two old fools fall out for two young wantons.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Indeed it becommeth men of our experience to reason, not rail: to debate the matter, not to combat it.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Well , then this I will tell thee friendly, I have almost these two years cast in my head, how I might match my princocks with Stellios daughter, whom I have heard to be very fair, and know shall be very rich, she is his heir, he dotes, he is stooping old, and shortly must die, yet by no means, either by blessing or cursing can I win my son to be a wooer, which I know proceeds not of bashfulness but stubornness, for he knows his good though I say it, he hath wit at will : as for his personage, I care not who sees him, I can tell you he is able to make a Ladies mouth water if she wink not.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Stay Sperantus, this is like my case, for I have been tampering as long to have a marriage committed between my wench and Memphios only son, they say he is as goodly a youth as one shall see in a Summers day, and as neat a stripling as ever went on neats leather, his father will not let him be forth of his sight, he is so tender over him, he yet lies with his mother for catching cold. Now my pretty elf, as proud as the day is long, she will none of him, she forsooth will choose her own husband, made marriages prove mad marriages, she will choose with her eye , and like with her heart before she consent with her tongue, neither father nor mother, kith nor kin shall be her carver in a husband, she will fall too where she likes best, and thus the chick scarce out of the shell cackles as though she had been trodden with an hundredth cocks, and mother of a thousand eggs.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Well then this is our best, seeing we know each others mind, to devise to govern our own children, for my boy, I will keep him to his books, and study shall make him leave to love, I will break him of his will or his bones with a cudgel.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And I will no more dandle my daughter, she shall prick on a clout till her fingers ache, or I will cause her leave to make my heart ache. But in good time, though with ill luck, behold if they be not both together, let us stand close and hear all, so shall we prevent all.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This happens pat, take heed you cough not Prisius.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Tush, spit not you, and I will warrant Aye , my beard is as good as a handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Liui.
sp.p: Sweet Candius, if thy father should see us alone, would he not fret? The old man methinks should be full of fumes.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: Tush, let him fret one heart string against another, he shall never trouble the least vain of my little finger, the old churl thinks none wise, unless he have a beard hang dangling to his waist, when my face is bedaubed with hair as his, then perchance my conceit may stumble on his staidness.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Aye in what book read you that lesson?

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I know not in what book he read it, but I am sure he was a knave to learn it.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I believe fair Liuia, if your sour sire should see you with your sweet heart, he would not be very patient.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: The care is taken, I will ask him blessing as a father, but never take counsel for an husband, there is as much odds between my golden thoughts, and his leaden advice, as between his silver hairs, and my amber locks, I know he will cough for anger that I yield not, but he shall cough me a fool for his labour.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Where picked your daughter that work, out of broad stitch?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Out of a flirts sampler, but let us stay the end, this is but the beginning, you shall hear two children well brought up.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Parents in these days are grown peevish, they rock their children in their cradles till they sleep, and cross them about their bridals till their hearts ache. Marriage among them is become a market, what will you give with your daughter? What Jointer will you make for your son? And many a match is broken off for a penny more or less, as though they could not afford their children at such a price, when none should cheapen such ware, but affection, and none buy it but love.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Learnedly and scholar-like.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Indeed our parents take great care to make us ask blessing, and say grace when we are little ones, and growing to years of judgement they deprive us of the greatest blessing, and the most gracious things to our minds, the liberty of our minds: they give us pap with a spoon before we can speak, and when we speak for that we love, pap with a hatchet: because their fancies being grown musty with hoary age, therefore nothing can relish in their thoughts that savours of sweet youth; they study twenty years together to make us grow as straight as a wand, and in the end, by bowing us, make us as crooked as a cammock. For mine own part (sweet Candius) they shall pardon me, for I will measure my love by mine own judgement, not my fathers purse or peevishness. Nature hath made me his child, not his slave, I hate Memphio and his son deadly, if I wist he would place his affection by his fathers appointment.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Wittily but uncivilly.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Be of that mind still my fair Liuia, let our fathers lay their purses together, we our hearts, I will never woo where I cannot love, let Stellio enjoy his daughter. But what have you wrought here?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Flowers, fowls, beasts, fishes, trees, plants, stones, and what not. Among flowers, cowslips and; lilies, for our names Candius and Liuia. Among fowls, Turtles and Sparrows, for our truth and desires. Among beasts, the Fox and the Ermine, for beauty and policy, and among fishes, the Cockle and the Tortoise, because of Venus among trees, the vine wreathing about the elm, for our embracings. Among stones, Abestor, which being hot will never be cold, for our constancies. Among plants, Time and Hearts-ease, to note, that if we take time, we shall ease our hearts.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: There is a girl that knows her lerripoope.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Listen and you shall hear my sons learning.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: What book is that?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: A fine pleasant Poet, who entreateth of the Art of Love, and of the remedy.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Is there Art in love?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: A short Art and a certain, three rules in three lines.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I pray thee repeat them.

p.foreign: Principio quod amare velis reperire labora Proximus huic labor est placidam exorare puellam Tertius vt longo tempore ducet amor

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I am no Latinist Candius you must conster it.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: So I will, and pace it too: thou shalt be acquainted with ease, gender, and number. First one must find out a Mistress, whom before all others he voweth to serve. Secondly, that he use all the means that he may to obtain her. And the last, with deserts, faith and secrecy, to study to keep her.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: What is the remedy?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Death.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: What of all the book is the conclusion?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: This one verse, Non caret effertu quod voluereduo.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Where two are agreed, it is impossible but they must speed.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Then cannot we miss, therefore give me thy hand Candius.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Soft Liuia, take me with you, it is not good in law without witness.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And as I remember, there must be two witnesses, God give you joy Candius, I was worth the bidding to dinner, though not worthy to be of the counsel.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I think this hot love hath provided but cold cheer.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Tush, in love is no lack, but blush not Candius, you need not be ashamed of your cunning, and have made love a book case, and spent your time well at school, learning to love by art, and hate against nature, but I perceive the worser child, the better lover.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And my minion hath wrought well, where every stitch in her sampler is a pricking stitch at my heart: you take your pleasure on parents, they are peevish, fools, churls, overgrown with ignorance, because overworn with age, little little shalt thou know the case of a father, before thyself be a mother, when thou shalt breed thy child with continual pains, and bringing it forth with deadly pangs, nurse it with thine own paps, and nourish it up with motherly tenderness, and then find them to curse thee with their hearts, when they should ask blessing on their knees, and the collop of thine own bowels to be the torture of thine own soul, with tears trickling down thy cheeks, and drops of blood falling from thy heart, thou wilt in uttering of thy mind, wish them rather unborn, than unnatural, and to have had their cradles their graves rather than thy death their bridals. But I will not dispute what thou shouldest have done, but correct what thou hast done, I perceive sowing is an idle exercise, and that every day there come more thoughts into thine head, than stitches into thy work, I will see whether you can spin a better mind than you have stitched, and if I coop you not up, then let me be the capon.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: As for you sir boy, instead of pouring on a book , you shall hold the plough, I will make repentance reap what wantonness hath sown, but we are both well served, the sons must be masters, the fathers gaffers, what we get together with a rake, they cast abroad with a fork, and we must weary our legs to purchase our children arms. Well, seeing that booking is but idleness, I will see whether threshing be any occupation, thy mind shall stoop to my fortune, or mine shall break the laws of nature. How like a micher he stands, as though he had truanted from honesty, get thee in, and for the rest let me alone. In villain.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And you pretty minx, that must be fed with Love upon sops, I will take an order to cram you with sorrows, get you in without look or reply.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Let us follow, and deal as rigorously with yours, as I will with mine, and you shall see that hot love will wax soon cold, I will tame the proud boy, and send him as far from his love as he is from his duty.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Let us about it, and also go on with matching them to our minds, it was happy that we prevented that by chance, which we could never yet suspect by circumstance.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Now if I could meet with Risio, it were a world of waggery.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: O that it were my chance Obuiam dare Dromio, to stumble upon Dromio, on whom I do nothing but dream.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: His knavery and my wit should make our Masters that are wise fools , their children that are fools, beggars, and us two that are bond, free.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: He to cozen, and I to conjure, would make such alterations, that our masters should serve themselves, the idiots their children serve us, and we to wake our wits between them all.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Hem qum opportune, look if he drop not full in my dish.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Lupus in fabula, Dromio embrace me, hug me, kiss my hand, I must make thee fortunate.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Risio, honour me, kneel down to me, kiss my feet, I must make thee blessed.

sp.speaker: Risio.
sp.p: My Master old Stellio hath a fool to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay, my Master old Memphio hath a fool to his son.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And I must convey a contract.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And I must convey a contract.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Between her and Memphios son without speaking one to another.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Between him and Stellios daughter, without one speaking to the other.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Dost thou mock me Dromio?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Thou dost me else.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Not I for all this is true.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And all this.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then are we both driven to our wits ends, for if either of them had been wise, we might have tempered, if no marriage, yet a close marriage.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well, let us sharpen our accounts, there is no better grindstone for a young man's head, than to have it whet upon an old man's purse. O thou shalt see my knavery shave like a razor!

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thou for the edge, and I the point, will make the fool bestride our Mistress backs, and then have at the bag with the dudgeon haste, that is, at the dudgeon dagger, by which hangs his tantonie pouch.

sp.speaker: Dromio.
sp.p: These old huddles have such strong purses with locks, when they shut them, they go off like a snaphance.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: The old fashion is best, a purse with a ring round about it, as a circle to course a knaves hand from it: but Dromino, two they say may keep counsel is one be away: but to convey knavery, two are too few, and four too many.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And in good time, look where Halfpenny Sperantus boy cometh, though bound up in decimo sexto for carriage, yet a wit in folio for cozenage. Single Halfpenny, what news are now current?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Nothing, but that such double coistrels as you be are counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Are you so dapper, we will send you for a halfpenny loaf.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I shall go for silver though, when you shall be nailed up for slips.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Thou art a slipstring I will warrant.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I hope you shall never slip string, but hang steady.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Dromio look here, now is my hand on my halfpenny.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Thou liest, thou hast not a farthing to lay thy hands on, I am none of thine: but let me be wagging, my head is full of hammers, and they have so malleted my wit, that I am almost a malcontent.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why, whats the matter?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: My master hath a fine scholar to his son, Prisius a fair lass to his daughter.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: They two love one another deadly.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: In good time.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: The fathers have put them up, utterly disliking the match, and have appointed the one shall have Memphios son, the other Stellios daughter, this works like wax, but how it will fadge in the end, the hen that sits next the cock cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: If thou have but any spice of knavery, we will make thee happy.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: Tush, doubt not of mine, I am as full for my pitch, as you are for yours, a wrens egg is as full of meat as a goose egg, though there be not so much in it: you shall find this head well stuffed , though there went little stuff to it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Laudo ingenium, I like thy sconce, then hearken: Memphio made me of his counsel about marriage of his son to Stellios daughter, Stellio made Riscio acquainted to plot a match with Memphios son. To be short, they be both fools.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: But they are not fools that be short, if I thought thou meanest so Senties qui virsim, Thou shouldest have a crow to pull.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Be not angry Halfpenny, for fellowship, we will be all fools, and for gain all knaves. But why dost thou laugh?

sp.speaker: Halfe.
sp.p: At mine own conceit and quick censure.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Suddenly me thought you two were asses, and that the least ass was the more ass.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thou art a fool, that cannot be.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Yea, my young master taught me to prove it by learning, and so I can out of Ouid by a verse.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: prithee how?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: You must first for fashion sake confess yourselves to be asses.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Then stand you here and you there.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Go to.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Then this is the verse as I point it, Cum mala per long as inualure moras. So you see the least ass is the more ass.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: We will bite thee for an ape, if thou bob us like asses. But to end all, if thou wilt join with us, we will make a match between the two fools, for that must be our tasks, and thou shalt devise to couple Candius and Liuia, by overreaching their fathers.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Let me alone, Non enim meapigra iuuentus, there is matter in this noddle.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: But look where Prisius boy comes, as fit as a pudding for a dogs mouth.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Pop three knaves in a sheath, I will make it a right Tunbridge case, and be the bodkin.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay, the bodkin is here already , you must be the knife.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I am the bodkin, look well to your ears, I must bore them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Mew thy tongue, or we will cut it out, this I speak representing the person of a knife, as thou didst that in shadow of a bodkin.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I must be gone, Tadet, it irketh, Oportet, it behooveth my wits work like barm, alias yeast, alias sizing, alias rising, alias Gods good.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: The new Wine is in thine head, yet was he fain to take this Metaphor from Ale, and now you talk of Ale, let us all to the Wine.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Four makes a mess, and we have a mess of Masters that must be cozened, let us lay our heads together, they are married and cannot.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Let us consult at the Tavern, where after to the health of Memphio, drink we to the life of Stellio, I carouse to Prisius, and brinch you master Sperantus, we shall cast us our accounts, and discharge our stomachs, like men that can digest anything .

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I see not yet what you go about.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Lucio that can pierce a mud wall of twenty foot thick, would make us believe he cannot see a candle through a paper lanthorn, his knavery is beyond Ela, and yet he says he knows not Gamut.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am ready, if any cozenage be ripe, I will shake the tree.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Nay, I hope to see thee so strong, to shake three trees at once.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: We burn time, for I must give a reckoning of my days work, let us close to the bush ad deliberandum.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Indeed Inter pocula philosophandum, it is good to plea among pots.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thine will be the worst, I fear we shall leave a Halfpenny in hand.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Why, sayst thou that thou hast left a print deeper in thy hand already than a halfpenny can leave , unless it should sing worse than an hot iron.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: All friends, and so let us sing, it is a pleasant thing to go into the Tavern, clearing the throat.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Then seal us for thy jolly Skinkers,

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.l: How dost thou the Noll refine!

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.l: Plump thou makest men's Ruby faces,
And from Girls canst fetch embraces;

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: O the dear blood of Grapes,
Now to show tricks like Apes,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Now flinging Hats in the fire.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Make us of thy Reeling Rabble.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I marvel I hear no news of Dromio, either he slacks the matter, or betrays his Master, I dare not motion anything to Stellio till I know what my Boy hath done ; I will hunt him out, if the Loiter-sack be gone springing into a Tavern, I will fetch him reeling out.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Without doubt Risio hath gone beyond himself, in casting beyond the Moon, I fear the Boy be run mad with studying, for I know he loved me so well, that for my favour he will venture to run out of his wits, and it may be, to quicken his invention, he is gone into this Ivy bush, a notable nest for a grape Owl, I will ferret him out, yet in the end use him friendly, I cannot be merry till I hear what is done in the Marriages.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I think Lucio be gone asquirrelling , but I will squirrel him for it, I sent him on my errand, but I must go for an answer myself , I have tied up the loving worm my daughter, and will see whether fancy can worm fancy out of her head, this green Nosegay I fear my Boy hath smelt too , for if he get but a penny in his purse, he turns it suddenly into Argentum potabile, I must search every place for him, for I stand on thorns till I hear what he hath done.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Well, be as be may is no banning, I think I have charmed my young Master, a hungry Meal, a ragged Coat, and a dry Cudgel, have put him quite beside his Love and his Logic too , besides Pigsny is put up, and therefore now I will let him take the air, and follow Stellios daughter with all his Learning, if he mean to be my heir, the Boy hath wit sans measure, more than needs, Cats meat and Dogs meat enough for the vantage. Well, without Halfpenny all my wit is not worth a dodkin, that mite is miching in this Grove, for as long as his name is Halfpenny, he will be banqueting, for the other Halfpenny.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: He must needs go that the Devil drives, a father, a fiend, that seeks to place affection by appointment, and to force love by compulsion, I have sworn to woo Sylena, but it shall be so coldly, that she take as small delight in my words, as I do contentment in his Commandment. I will teach him one school-trick in love. But behold, who is that that cometh out of Stellios house? it should seem to be Silena by her attire,

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: by her face I am sure it is she, o fair face, o lovely countenance. How now Candius, if thou begin to slip at beauty on a sudden, thou wilt surfeit with a carousing it at the last. Remember that Liuia is faithful, Aye , and let thine eyes witness Silena is amiable, here shall I please my father and myself , I will learn to be obedient, and come what will, I will make away, if she seem coy, I will practise all the Art of Love if I her cunning, all the pleasures of Love.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My name is Silena I care not who know it, so I do not: my father keeps me close, so he does, and now I have stolen out, so I have, to go to old Mother Bombie to know my fortune, so I will, for I have as fair a face as ever trod on shoe sole, and as free a foot as ever looked with two eyes.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: What, I think she is lunatic or foolish? Thou art a fool Candius, so fair a face cannot be the scabbard of a foolish mind, mad she may be , for commonly in beauty so rare, there falls passions extreme, Love and beauty disdain a mean, not therefore because beauty is no virtue, but because it is happiness , and we Scholars know that virtue is not to be praised, but honoured. I will put on my best grace, sweet Wench, thy face is lovely, thy body comely, and all that the eyes can see enchanting, you see how unacquainted I am bold to board you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: My Father boards me already, therefore I care not if your name were Geoffrey.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: She raves or overreaches. I am one sweet soul that loves you, brought hither by report of your beauty, and here languisheth with your rareness.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I thank you that you would call.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I will always call on such a Saint that hath power to release my sorrows, yield fair creature to Love.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I am none of that Sect.

sp.speaker: Candius.
sp.p: The loving Sect is an ancient Sect, and an honourable, and therefore should be in a person so perfect.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Much.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I love thee much, give me one word of comfort.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Aye faith sir no, and so tell your Master.

sp.speaker: Cand.
sp.p: I have no Master, but come to make choice of a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Aha, are you there with your Bears.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Doubtless she is an Idiot of the newest cut, I will once more try her . I have loved thee long Silena.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: In your the other hose.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Too simple to be natural: too senseless to be artificial. You said you went to know your fortune, I am a Scholar, and am cunning in Palmistry.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: The better for you sir, here is my hand, what is o'clock ?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: The line of life is good, Venus mount very perfect, you shall have a scholar to your first husband.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: You are well seen in Carnes dirt, your Father was a Poulter, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Why laugh you?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Because you should see my teeth.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Alas poor wench, I see now also thy folly, a fair fool is like a fresh weed, pleasing leaves, and sour juice, I will not yet leave her, she may dissemble. I cannot choose but love thee.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I had thought to ask you.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Nay then farewell, either too proud to accept, or too simple to understand.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: You need not be so crusty , you are not so hard backed.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Now I perceive thy folly, who hath raked together all the odd blind phrases, that help them that know not how to discourse, but when they cannot answer wisely, either with gibing cover their rudeness, or by some new coined by-word bewray their peevishness , I am glad of this, now shall I have colour to refuse the match, and my father reason to accept of Liuia, I will home, and repeat to my father our wise encounter, and he shall perceive there is nothing so fulsome as a she fool .

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Good God, I think Gentlemen had never less wit in a year. We maids are mad Wenches, we gird them and flout them out of all scotch and notch, and they cannot see it, I will know of the old woman whether I be a Maid or no, and then if I be not, I must needs be a man, God be here .

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Who is there?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: One that would be a maid.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: If thou be not, it is impossible thou shouldest be, and a shame thou art not.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: They say you are a Witch.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: They lie, I am a cunning Woman.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Then tell me something .

sp.speaker: Bomb.
sp.p: Hold up thy hand, not so high, thy father knows thee not, thy Mother bare thee not, falsely bred, truly begot, choice of two husbands, but never tied in bands, because of Love and natural bonds.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I thank you for nothing, because I understand nothing: though you be as old as you are, yet am I as young as I am, and because that I am so fair, therefore are you so foul and so farewell frost, my fortune naught me cost.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Farewell fair fool, little dost thou know thy hard fortune, but in the end thou shalt, and that must bewray what none can discover, in the mean season I will profess cunning for all comers.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: We are all taken tardy.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Our Masters will be overtaken if they tarry.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Now must everyone by wit make an excuse, and every excuse must be cozenage.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Let us remember our complot.

sp.speaker: Dromio.
sp.p: We will all plod on that, o the Wine hath turned my wit to Vinegar.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: You mean it is sharp.

sp.speaker: Halfe.
sp.p: sharp? I will warrant it will serve for as good sauce to knavery as.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: As what?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: As thy knavery meat for his wit.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: We must all give a reckoning for our days travel.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Tush, I am glad we escaped the reckoning for our liquor. If you be examined how we met, swear by chance, for so they met, and therefore will believe it: if how much we drunk, let them answer themselves, they know best because they paid it.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: We must not tarry, abeundum est mihi, I must go and cast this matter in a corner.

sp.speaker: Dromio
sp.p: I presequar, a bowl, and I will come after with a broom, everyone remember his cue.

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Aye and his K. or else we shall thrive ill.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: When shall we meet?

sp.speaker: Ris.
sp.p: Tomorrow fresh and fasting.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Fast eating our meat, for we have drunk for tomorrow , and tomorrow we must eat for today .

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Away, away, if our Masters take us here, the matter is marred.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Let us everyone to his task.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: How quickly we met on a sudden in a Tavern, that drunk not together almost these thirty years.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: A Tavern is the Rendezvous , the Exchange, the staple for good fellows : I have heard my great Grandfather tell how his great Grandfather should say , that it was an old Proverb, when his great Grandfather was a child, that it was a good wind that blew a man to the Wine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The old time was a good time, Ale was an ancient drink, and accounted of our Ancestors authentical, Gascon wine was liquor for a Lord, Sack a medicine for the sick, and I may tell you, he that had a cup of red Wine to his Oysters, was hoisted in the Queens Subsidy book.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Aye but now you see to what looseness this age is grown, our boys carouse Sack like double Beer, and saith, that which doth an old man good, can do a young man no harm: old men (say they) eat pap, why should not children drink sack, their white heads have cozened time out of mind our young years.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Well, the World is wanton since I knew it first, our Boys put as much now in their bellies in an hour, as would cloth their whole bodies in a year, we have paid for their tippling eight shillings, and as I have heard, it was as much as bought Rufus, sometime King of this Land, a pair of hose.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Is it possible?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Nay, it is true, they say , Ale is out of request, it is Hogs porridge, broth for beggars, a Caudle for Constables, Watchmens mouth glue, the better it is, the more like bird-lime it is, and never makes one staid but in the stocks.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: I will teach my Wag-halter to know Grapes from Barley.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And I mine, to discern a spigot from a faucet.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And I mine, to judge the difference between a black bowl and a silver goblet.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: And mine shall learn the odds between a Stand and a Hogshead, yet I cannot choose but laugh to see how my Wag answered me, when I struck him for drinking Sack.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why what said he?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Master, it is the sovereignest drink in the World, and the safest for all times and weathers, if it thunder, though all the Ale and Beer in the Town turn, it will be constant; if it lighten, and that any fire come to it, it is the aptest Wine to burn, and the most wholesomest when it is burnt. So much for Summer. If it freeze, why it is so hot in operation, that no Ice can congeal it, if it rain, why then he that cannot abide the heat of it, may put in water. So much for Winter. And so ran his way, but I will overtake him.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Who would think that my hop on my thumb, Halfpenny, scarce so high as a pint pot, would reason the matter, but he learned his leerof my son, his young Master, whom I have brought up at Oxford, and I think must learn here in Kent at Ashford.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Why what said he?

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: He boldly rapt it out, Sine Cere and Baccho friget Venus, without Wine and Sugar his Veins would wax cold.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: They were all in a pleasant vein, but I must be gone, and take account of my boys business; farewell neighbours, God knows when we shall meet again, yet have discovered nothing, my Wine hath been my wits friend, I long to hear what Dromio hath done.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I cannot stay, but this good fellowship shall cost me the setting on at our next meeting. I am glad I blabbed nothing of the marriage, now I hope to compass it, I know my boy hath been bungling about it.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Let us all go, for I must to my clothes that hang on the tenters, my boy shall hang with them, if he answer me not his days work.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: If all be gone, I will not stay, Halfpenny I am sure hath done me a penny worth of good, else I will spend his body in buying a rod.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: Sweet sister, I know not how it cometh to pass, but I find in myself passions more than brotherly.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And I dear brother find my thoughts entangled with affections beyond nature, which so flame into my distempered head, that I can neither without danger smother the fire, nor without modesty disclose my fury.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: Our Parents are poor, our love unnatural, what can then happen to make us happy?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Only to be content with our fathers mean estate, to combat against our own intemperate desires, and yield to the success of fortune, who though she hath framed us miserable, cannot make us monstrous.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: It is good counsel fair sister, if the necessity of Love could be relieved by counsel, yet this is our comfort, that these unnatural heats have stretched themselves no further than thoughts, unhappy me that they should stretch so.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: That which nature warranteth laws forbid, strange it seemeth in sense, that because thou art mine, therefore thou must not be mine.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: So it is Serena the nearer we are in blood, the further we must be from love, and the greater the kindred is, the less the kindness must be, so that between brothers and sisters, superstition hath made affection cold, between strangers custom hath bred Love exquisite.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They say there is hard by an old cunning Woman, who can tell fortunes, expound dreams, tell of things that be lost, and divine of accidents to come, she is called the good woman, who yet never did hurt.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: Nor any good I think Serena, yet to satisfy thy mind, we will see what she can say .

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Good brother let us.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: Who is within?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: The Dame of the house.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: She might have said the Beldam, for her face and years, and attire.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Good mother tell us, if by your cunning you can, what shall become of my brother and me?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Let me see your hands, and look on me steadfastly with your eyes. You shall be married tomorrow hand in hand, and by the Laws of God, Nature, and the Land, your Parents shall be glad, and give you their Land, you shall each of you displace a fool, and both together must relieve a fool. If this be not true, then call me old fool.

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: This is my sister, marry we cannot: our Parents are poor and have no Land to give us, each of us is a fool, to come for counsel to such an old fool.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: These doggerel rhymes and obscure words, coming out of the mouth of such a weather-beaten Witch, are thought Divinations of some holy Spirit, being but Dreams of decayed brains , for mine own part, I would thou mightst sit on that stool, till he and I marry by Law.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: I say Mother Bombie never speaks but once, and yet never spake untruth once.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Come brother, let us to our poor home, this is our comfort, to bewray our passions, since, we cannot enjoy our love .

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: Content sweet sister, and learn of me hereafter, that these old saws of such old Hags, are but false fires to lead one out of a plain path into a deep pit.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ingenium quondam fuerat pretiotius auro, the time was wherein wit would work like wax and crock up Gold like Honey.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: At nunc barbarie est grandis habere nihil, but now wit and honesty buy nothing in the Market.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What Risio how spedest thou after thy potting?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay, my Master rung all in the Tavern, and thrust all out in the house. But how spedest thou?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Aye , it were a days work to discourse it, he spake nothing but sentences, but they were vengible long ones, for when one word was out, he made pause of a quarter long, till he spake another.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Why what did he in all that time?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Break Interjections like wind, as eho, ho to.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And what thou?

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: Answer him in his own language, as euax, vah, bui.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: These were Conjunctions rather than Interjections. But what of the plot?

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: As we concluded, I told him that I understood that Silena was very wise, and could sing exceedingly, that my device was, seeing Accius his son a proper youth, and could also sing sweetly, that he should come in the nick when she was singing, and answer her.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then he asked how it should be deviced that she might come abroad, I told that was cast already by my means, then the Song being ended, and they seeing one another, noting the apparel, and marking the personages, he should call in his son for fear he should overreach his speech.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: Then that I had gotten a young Gentleman, that resembled his son in years and favour, that having Accius apparel should court Silena, whom she finding wise, would after that by small entreaty be won without more words, and so the marriage clapped up by this cozenage, and his son never speak word for himself.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Thou boy, so have I done in every point, for the Song, the calling her in, and the hoping that another shall woo Accius, and his Daughter wed him, I told him this wooing should be to night, and they early married in the morning, without any words saving to say after the Priest.

sp.speaker: Drom.
sp.p: All this fadges well, now if Halfpenny and Lucio have played their parts, we shall have excellent sport, and here they come. Howe wrought the Wine my Lads?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: How? like Wine, for my body being the rundlet, and my mouth the vent, it wrought two days over, till I had thought the hoops of my head would have flown asunder.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: The best was our Masters were as well whittled as we, for yet they lie by it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The better for us, we did but a little parboil our livers, they have sod theirs in Sack these forty years.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: That makes them spit white broth as they do. But to the purpose. Candius and Liuia will send their attires, you must send the apparel of Accius and Silena, they wonder wherefore, but commit the matter to our quadrapertit wit.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: If you keep promise to marry them by your device, and their Parents consent, you shall have ten pounds apiece for your pains.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: If we do it not we are undone, for we have broached a cozenage already, and my master hath the tap in his hand, that it must needs run out; let them be ruled, and bring hither their apparel , and we will determine, the rest commit to our intricate considerations, depart.
Here comes Accius tuning his Pipes, I perceive my Master keeps touch.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And here comes Silena with her wit of proof, marry it will scarce hold our question shot, let us in to instruct out masters in the cue.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Come let us be jogging, but wert not a world to hear them woe one another.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: That shall be hereafter to make us sport, but our masters shall never know it.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.l: Wherefore hast thou feet and wings?
It is to show how swift thou art,
When thou woundest a tender heart,
Thy wings being clipped, and feet held
Thy Bow so many could not kill.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.l: It is all one in Venus wanton
Who highest sits, the wise man or the fool:

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Accius come in, and that quickly, what walking without leave?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Silena, I pray you look homeward, it is a cold air, and you want your muffler.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: This is pat, if the rest proceed Stellio is like to marry his daughter to a fool, but a bargain is a bargain.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This frames to my wish, Memphio is like to marry a fool to his son, Accius tongue shall tie all Memphios land to Silenas dowry, let his fathers teeth undo them if he can; but here I see Memphio, I must seem kind for in kindness lies cozenage.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Well , here is Stellio I will talk of other matters, and fly from the mark I shoot at, lapwing-like flying far from the place where I nestle. Stellio what make you abroad? I heard you were sick since our last drinking.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: You see reports are no truths, I heard the like of you, and we are both well. I perceive sober men tell most lies, for in vino veritas. If they had drunk wine, they would have told the truth.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Our boys will be sure then never to lie, for they are ever swilling of wine; but Stellio I must strain curtsy with you, I have business I cannot stay.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: In good time Memphio for I was about to crave your patience to depart, it stands me upon. Perhaps move his patience ere it be long.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Good silly Stellio we must buckle shortly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Come Rixula we have made thee privy to the whole pack, there lay down the pack.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: I believe unless it be better handled, we shall out of doors.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I care not, Omne Solum forti patria, I can live in Christendom as well as in Kent.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: And I will sing Patria vbicunque bene, every house is my home, where I may stanch hunger.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Nay, if you set all on hazard, though I be a poor wench I am as hardy as you both, I cannot speak Latin but in plain English, if anything fall out cross I will run away.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: He loves thee well that would run after.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Why Halfpenny, there is no goose so gray in the lake, that cannot find a gander for her make.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I love a nut brown lass, it is good to recreate.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Thou meanest, a brown nut is good to crack.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Why would it not do thee good to crack such a nut?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I fear she is worm-eaten within, she is so moth-eaten without.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: If you take your pleasure of me , I will in and tell your practises against your Masters.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: In faith sour heart, he that takes his pleasure on thee, is very pleasurable.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: You mean knavishly, and yet I hope foul water will quench hot fire as soon as fair.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Well then, let fair words cool that choler, which foul speeches hath kindled, and because we are all in this case, and hope all to have good fortune, sing a roundelay, and we will help, such as thou wast wont when thou beatest hemp.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: It was crabs she stamped, and stole away one to make her a face.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: I agree, in hope that the hemp shall come to your wearing, a halfpenny halter may hang you both, that is, Halfpenny and you may hang in a halter.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Well brought about.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: It will when it is about your neck.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nay, now she is in, she will never out.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Nor when your heads are in, as it is likely, they should not come out. But hearken to my song.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.l: Then thought I of nothing but hanging,
Then I wished for a noise
On Those hempen strings to be twanging,

sp.speaker: 4.Pag.
sp.l: And found no such fiddling varlets.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.l: Phip, phip, the sparrows as they fly,
The goose does hiss, the duck cries quack,
A Rope the Parrot, that holds tack.

sp.speaker: 4.Pa.
sp.l: The parrot and the rope be thine.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.l: The hanging yours, but the hemp

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yonder stands the wags, I am come in good time.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: All here before me, you make haste.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: I believe to hanging, for I think you have all robbed your masters, here is every man his baggage.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: That is, we are all with thee, for thou art a very baggage.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Hold thy peace, or of mine honesty I will buy an halfpenny purse with thee.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Indeed that is big enough to put thy honesty in, but come, shall we go about the matter?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Now it is come to the pinch my heart pants.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I for my part am resolute, in vtrana, paratus, ready to die or to run away.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But hear me, I was troubled with a vile dream, and therefore it is little time spent to let Mother Bombie expound it, she is cunning in all things.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then will I know my fortune.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: And I will ask for a silver spoon which was lost last day, which I must pay for.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And I will know what will become of our devices.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then let us all go quickly, we must not sleep in this business, our masters are so watchful about it.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Why do you rap so hard at the door?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Because we would come in.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Nay my house is no Inn.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: Cross yourselves , look how she looks.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Mark her not, she will turn us all to Apes.

sp.speaker: Bomb.
sp.p: What would you with me?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: They say you are cunning, and are called the good woman of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: If never to do harm, be to do good, I dare say I am not ill. But what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I had an ill dream, and desire to know the signification.

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Dreams my son have their weight, though they be of a troubled mind, yet are they signs of fortune. Say on.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: In the dawning of the day, for about that time by my starting out of my sleep, I found it to be, methought I saw a stately piece of beef, with a cape cloak of cabbage, embroidered with pepper, having two honourable pages with hats of mustard on their heads, himself in great pomp sitting upon a cushion of white Brewish, lined with brown bread, methought being powdered, he was much troubled with the salt rheum, and therefore there stood by him two great flagons of sack and beer, the one to dry up his rheum, the other to quench his choler, I as one envying his ambition, hungering and thirsting after his honour, began to pull his cushion from under him hoping by that means to give him a fall, and with putting out my hand awakened, and found nothing in all this dream about me but the salt rheum.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: A dream for a butcher.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Soft let me end it, then I slumbered again, and methought there came in a leg of mutton.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: What all gross meat, a rack had been dainty.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Thou fool, how could it come in, unless it had been a leg, methought his hose were cut and; drawn out with parsley, I thrust my hand into my pocket for a knife, thinking to hox him, and so awakened.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Belike thou wentest supperless to bed.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: So I do every night but Sundays, Prisius hath a weak stomach, and therefore we must starve.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Well, take this for answer, though the dream be fantastical, they that in the morning sleep dream of eating, are in danger of sickness, or of beating, or shall hear of a wedding fresh abeating .

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: This may be true.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Nay then let me come in with a dream, short but sweet, that my mouth waters ever since I waked. Methought there sat upon a shelf three damask prunes in velvet caps, and pressed satin gowns like Judges, and that there were a whole handful of currants to be arraigned of riot, because they clunged together in such clusters, twelve raisins of the sun were impanelled in a Jury, and as a leaf of whole mace which was Bailiff, was carrying the quest to consult, methought there came an angry cook, and gelded the Jury of their stones, and swept both Judges, Jurors, rebels and Bailiff, into a porridge pot, whereat I being melancholy, fetched a deep sigh, that waked my myself and my bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: This was deviced not dreamed, and the more foolish being no dream, for that dreams excuse the fantasticalness.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Then ask my bedfellow, you know him, who dreamed that night that the king of diamonds was sick.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: But thy years and humours pretty child, are subject to such fancies, which the more unsensible they seem, the more fantastical they are, therefore this dream is easy. To children, this is given from the Gods to dream of milk, fruit, babies, and rods, they betoken nothing, but that wantons must have rods.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Ten to one thy dream is true, thou wilt be swinged.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Nay gammer, I pray you tell me who stole my spoon out of the buttery.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Thy spoon is not stolen but mislaid, thou art an ill housewife, though a good maid, look for thy spoon where thou hadst like to be no maid.

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Body of me let me fetch the spoon, I remember the place.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Soft swift, the place if it be there now, will be there tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: Aye but perchance the spoon will not.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Wert thou once put to it?

sp.speaker: Rix.
sp.p: No sir boy, it was put to me.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How was it missed?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I will warrant for want of a mist. But what is my fortune mother?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.p: Thy father doth live because he doth die, thou hast spent all thy thrift with a die, and so like a beggar thou shalt die.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I would have liked well if all the gerunds had been there, di, do, and dum, but all in die, that is too deadly.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: My father indeed is a dyer, but I have been a dicer, but to die a beggar, give me leave not to believe Mother Bombie, and yet it may be. I have nothing to live by but knavery and if the world grow honest, welcome beggary. But what hast thou to say Risio?

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nothing, till I see whether all this be true that she hath said.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I Risio, would fain see thee beg.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay mother tell us this, What is all our fortunes, we are about a matter of legerdemain , how will it fadge?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: You shall all thrive like cozeners, that is, to be cozened by cozeners: all shall end well, and you be found cozeners.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: Gramercy Mother Bombie we are all pleased, if you were for your pains.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: I take no money, but good words, rail not if I tell true, if I do not revenge. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Now have we nothing to do, but to go about this business, Accius apparel let Candius put on, and I will array Accius with Candius clothes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Here is Silenas attire, Linceo put it upon Liuia, and give me Liuias for Silena, this done, let Candius and Liuia come forth, and let Dromio and me alone for the rest.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: What shall become of Accius and Silena?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Tush, their turn shall be next, all must be done orderly, let us to it, for now it works.

body.stage: Candius, Liuia, Dromio, Risio, Sperantus, Prisius.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: This attire is very fit. But how if this make me a fool, and Silena wise, you will then woo me, and wed her.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Thou knowest that Accius is also a fool, and his raiment fits me, so that if apparel be infectious, I am also like to be a fool, and he wist what would be the conclusion, I marvel.

sp.speaker: Li.
sp.p: Here comes our Counsellors.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Well said, I perceive Turtles fly in couples.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Else how should they couple?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: So do knaves go double, else how should they be so cunning in doubling?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Bona verba, Liuia.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I understand Latin, that is, Liuia is a good word.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: No I bid her use good words.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And what deeds?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: None but a deed of gift.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: What gift?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Her heart.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Give me leave to pose you though you be a graduate, for I tell you, we in Rochester spur so many hackneys, that we must needs spur scholars , for we take them for hackneys.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Why so sir boy?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Because I knew two hired for ten groats a piece to say service on Sunday, and that is no more than a post horse from hence to Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: He knows what he says , for he once served the Post-master.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Indeed I think he served some post to his Master, but come Dromio post me.

sp.speaker: Dr.
sp.p: You say you would have her heart for a deed.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: If you take her heart for cor, that heart in her body, then know this: Molle eius leuibies, Cor enim inuiolabile telis, A woman's heart is thrust through with a feather: if you mean she should give a heart named Ceruus, then are you worse, for cornua ceruus habet, that is, to have ones heart grow out at his head, which will make one ache at the heart in their body.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: I beshrew your hearts, hear one coming, I know it is my father by his coming.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: What must we do?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Why as I told you, and let me alone with the old men, fall you to your bridal.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Come neighbour, I perceive the love of our children waxeth key cold.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I think it was never but luke warm.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Bavins will have their flashes, and youth their fancies, the one as soon quenched as the other burned, but who be these?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Here I do plight my faith, taking thee for the staff of my age, and of my youth my solace.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: And I vow to thee affection which nothing can dissolve, neither the length of time, nor malice of fortune, nor distance of place.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: But when shall we be married?

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: A good question, for that one delay in wedding, brings an hundred dangers in the Church, we will not be asked, and a licence is too chargeable, and to tarry till tomorrow too tedious.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: There is a girl stands on pricks till she be married.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: To avoid danger, charge and tediousness, let us now conclude it in the next Church.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: What be these that hasten so to marry?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marry sir, Accius son to Memphio, and Silena Stellios daughter.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I am sorry neighbour, for our purposes are disappointed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: You see marriage is destiny, made in heaven, though consummated on earth.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: How like you them, be they not a pretty couple?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Yes God give them joy, seeing in spite of our hearts they must join.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I am sure you are not angry, seeing things past cannot be recalled, and being witnesses to their contract, will be also well-willers to the match.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: For my part I wish them well.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And I, and since there is no remedy, that I am glad of it.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: But will you never hereafter take it in dudgeon, but use them as well as though yourselves had made the marriage?

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Not, I.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Sir, here is two old men are glad that your loves so long continued, is so happily concluded.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: We thank them, and if they will come to Memphios house, they shall take part of a bad dinner. This cottons and works like wax in a sows ear.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well, seeing our purposes are prevented, we must lay other plots, for Liuia shall not have Candius.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Fear not, for I have sworn that Candius shall not have Liuia. But let not us fall out because our children fall in.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Wilt thou go soon to Memphios house?

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Aye and if you will let us, that we may see how the young couple bride it, and so we may teach our own.

body.stage: Linceo "T" in stage direction becomes speaker Liu in speech and so came to be attributed to Liuia "G". However Andreadus notes Dilke emends Linceo to Lucio "K" which seems to fit better.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: By this time I am sure the wags have played their parts, there rests nothing now for us, but to match Acccius and Silena.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: It was too good to be true, for we should laugh heartily, and without laughing my spleen would split, but whist, here comes the man.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: and yonder the maid, let us stand aside.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: What means my father to thrust me forth in an other boys coat?I will warrant it is to as much purpose as a hem in the forehead.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: There was an ancient Proverb knocked in the head.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I am almost come into my nonage, and yet I never was so far as the proverbs of this city.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: There is a quip for the suburbs of Rochester.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Excellently applied.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Well, though this furniture make me a sullen dame, yet I hope in mine own I am no saint.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: A brave fight is likely like to be between a cock with a long comb, and a hen with a long leg.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay her wits are shorter than her legs.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And his comb longer than his wit.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I have yonder uncovered a fair girl, I will be so bold as spur her, what might a body call her name?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I cannot help you at this time, I pray you come again tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Aye marie sir.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: You need not be so lusty, you are not so honest.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, I took you for a joined stool.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Here is courting for a conduit or a bakehouse.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: But what are you for a man? methinks you look as pleaseth God.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: What do you give me the boots?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Whether will they, here be right cobblers cuts.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I am taken with a fit of love: Have you any mind of marriage?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I had thought to have asked you.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Upon what acquaintance?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Who would have thought it?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Much in my gaskins, more in my round hose, all my fathers are as white as daisies, as an egg full of meat.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: And all my fathers plate is made of Crimson velvet.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: That brave with bread.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: These three had wise men to their fathers.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Because when their bodies were at work about household stuff, their minds were busied about commonwealth matters.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: This is pure lawn: What call you this, a preface to your hair?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Wisely you have picked a raisin out of a frail of figs.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Take it as you list, you are in your own clothes.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Saving a reverence that is a lie, my clothes are better, my father borrowed these.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Long may he so do, I could tell that these are not mine, if I would blab it like a woman.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I had as lief you should tell them it snowed.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Come let us take them off, for we have had the cream of them.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I will warrant if this be the cream, the milk is very flat, let us join issue with them.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: To have such issue of our bodies, is worse than have an issue in the body. God save you pretty mouse.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: You may command and go without.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: There is glick for you, let me have my gird, on thy conscience tell me what it is a clock?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I cry you mercy, I have killed your cushion?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I am paid and struck dead in the nest, I am sure this soft youth, who is not half so wise as you are fair, nor you altogether so fair as he is foolish, will not be so captious.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Your eloquence passes my recognisance .

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I never heard that before, but shall we two make a match between you?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I will know first who was his father.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: My father, what need you to care, I hope he was none of yours.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: A hard question, for it is odds but one begat them both, he that cut out the upper Leather, cut out the inner, and so with one Awl stitched two soles, together.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: What is she?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: It is Prisius daughter.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: In good time it fadges.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sperantus son.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: So it will cotton.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Damsel, I pray you how old are you?

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: My son would scarce have asked such a foolish question.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I shall be eighteen next Bear-baiting.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: My daughter would have made a wiser answer.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: O how fitly this comes of!

sp.speaker: Accius.
sp.p: My father is a scold, what is yours?

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: My heart throbs, I look him in the face, and yonder I espy Stellio.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: My mind misgives me, but whist, yonder is Memphio.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: In faith I perceive an old saw, and a rusty, no fool to the old fool. I pray you wherefore was I thrust out like a scarecrow in this similitude?

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: My son and I ashamed, Dromio shall die.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Father are you sneaking behind, I pray you what must I do next?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: My daughter, Risio thou hast cozened me.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Now begins the game.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: How came you hither?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Marry by the way from house hither.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: How chance in this attire?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: How chance Dromio bid me?

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Ah thy son will be begged for a concealed fool.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Will I, Aye faith sir no.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Wherefore came you hither Silena without leave?

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Because I did , and I am here because I am.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: poor Wench, thy wit is improved to the uttermost.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Aye , it is an hard matter to have a wit of the old rent, everyone racks his Commons so high.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Dromio told me that one should meet Stellios daughter, and court her in person of my son.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Risio told me one should meet Memphios son, and plead in place of my daughter.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: But alas I see that my son hath met with Silena himself, and bewrayed his folly.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: But I see my Daughter hath prattled with Accius, and discovered her simplicity.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: A brave cry to hear the two old Mules to weep over the young fools.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Accius how likest thou Silena?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I take her to be pregnant.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Truly his talk is very personable.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Come in Girl, this gear must be fetched about.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Come Accius let us go in.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay sir, there is no harm done, they have neither bought nor sold, they may be twins for their wits and years.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: But why didst thou tell me it was Prisius son?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Because I thought thee a fool, to ask who thine own son was.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And so sir for your Daughter, education hath done much, otherwise they are by nature soft witted enough.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Alas their joints are not yet tied, they are not yet come to years and discretion.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Father, if my hands be tied, shall I grow wise?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Aye and Silena too , if you tie them fast to your tongues.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: You may take your pleasure of my tongue, for it is no man's Wife.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Come in Accius.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Come in Silena, I will talk with Memphios son, but as for Risio.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: As for Dromio.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: As for you all four.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: How goes the World, now we have made all sure, Candius and Liuia are married, their fathers consenting, yet not knowing.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: We have flat marred all, Accius and Silena courted one another, their fathers took them napping, both are ashamed, and you both shall be swinged.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Tush, let us alone, we will persuade them that all falls out for the best, for if underhand this match had been concluded, they both had been cozened, and now seeing they find both to be fools, they may be both better advised. But why is Halfpenny so sad?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Because I am sure I shall never be a penny.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Rather pray there be no fall of money, for thou wilt then go for a cue.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: But did not the two fools currently court one another.

sp.speaker: Liu.
sp.p: Very good words fitly applied, brought in the nick.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: I arrest you.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Me sir, why then didst not bring a stool with thee, that I might sit down?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: He arrests you at my suite for a horse.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The more Ass he, if he had arrested a Mare instead of an Horse, it had been but a slight oversight, but to arrest a man that hath no likeness of a horse, is flat lunacy or alecie.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Tush, I hired him a horse.

sp.speaker: Dromio.
sp.p: I swear then he was well ridden.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I think in two days he was never baited.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Why was it a Bear thou ridest on?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I mean he never gave him bait.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Why he took him for no fish.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I mistake none of you when I take you for fools, I say thou never gavest my horse meat.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes, in four and forty hours I am sure he had a bottle of hay as big as his belly.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Nothing else, thou shouldest have given him provender.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Why he never asked for any .

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Why, dost thou think an horse can speak?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: No, for I spurred him till my heels ached and he said never a word.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Well, thou shalt pay sweetly for spoiling him, it was as lusty a Nag as any in Rochester, and one that would stand upon no ground.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then he is as good as ever he was, I will warrant he will do nothing but lie down.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I lent him thee gently.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: And I restored him so gently, that he neither would cry wehee, nor wag the tail.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: But why didst thou bore him thorough the ears?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: It may be he was set on the pillory, because he had not a true pace.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: No, it was for tiring.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: He would never tire, it may be he would be so weary, he would go no further, or so.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes he was a notable horse for service, he would tire, and retire.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Do you think I will be jested out of my horse? Sergeant wreak thine office on him.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Nay, stay, let him be bailed.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: So he shall when I make him a bargain.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: It was a very good horse I must needs confess, and now hearken of his qualities, and have patience to hear them, since I must pay for him. He would stumble three hours in one mile, I had thought I had rode upon addeces between this and Canterbury: if one gave him water, why he would lie down and bath himself like a Hawk: if one ran him, he would simper and mump, as though he had gone a-wooing to a Malt-mare at Rochester: he trotted before and ambled behind, and was so obedient, that he would do duty every minute on his knees, as though every stone had been his father.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I am sure he had no diseases.

sp.speaker: Dro.
