sp.p: A little rheum or pose, he lacked nothing but an handkerchief.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Come, what a tale of a horse have we here, I cannot stay, thou must with me to prison.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: If thou be a good fellow Hackneyman, take all our four bonds for the payment, thou knowest we are Town born children, and will not shrink the City for a pelting jade.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I will enter into a Statute Merchant to see it answered. But if thou wilt have bonds, thou shalt have a bushel full.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Alas poor Ant, thou bound in a Statute Merchant: a brown thread will I bind thee fast enough: but if you will be content all four jointly to enter into a bond, I will withdraw the Action.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Yes I will warrant they will. How say you?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: I yield.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Well, call the Scrivener.

sp.speaker: Serg.
sp.p: Here is one hard by, I will call him.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: A Scriveners shop hangs to a Sergeants Mace, like a burr to a freeze coat.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: You must take a note of a bond.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay, a pint of courtsey pulls on a pot of Wine, in this Tavern we will dispatch.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Now if our wits be not in the wane, our knavery shall be at the full, they will ride them worse than Dromio rid his horse, for if the Wine master their wits, you shall see them bleed their follies.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Every Fox to his hole, the hounds are at hand.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: The Sergeants Mace lies at pawn for the reckoning, and he under the board to cast it up.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: The Scrivener cannot keep his pen out of the pot, every goblet is an inkhorn.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: The Hackneyman he whisks with his Wand, as if the Tavern were his Stable, and all the servants his horses, jost there up, bay Richard and White Loaves are horse-bread in his eyes.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: It is well I have my acquaintance, and he such a bond as shall do him no more good than the bond of a faggot, our knaveries are now come to the push, and we must cunningly dispatch all, we two will go see how we may appeal our Masters, you two how you may conceal the late marriage, if all fall out amiss, the worst is beating, if to the best the worst is liberty.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then let us about it speedily, for so many irons in the together require a diligent Plumber.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My heart throbs, my ears tingle, my mind misgives me , since I hear such muttering of Marriages in Rochester my conscience which these eighteen years hath been frozen with congealed guiltiness, begins now to thaw in open grief, but I will not accuse myself till I see more danger, the good old Woman Mother Bombie shall try her cunning upon me, and if I perceive my case is desperate by her, then will I rather prevent, although with shame, then report too late, and be inexcusable. God speed good Mother.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Welcome sister.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I am troubled in the night with dreams, and in the day with fears, mine estate bare, which I cannot well bear, but my practices devilish, which I cannot recall, if therefore in these same years there be any deep skill tell me what my fortune shall be, and what my fault is.

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: In studying to be overnatural , thou art like to be unnatural, and all about a natural: thou shalt be eased of a charge, if thou thy conscience discharge, and this I commit to thy charge.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Thou hast touched me to the quick mother, I understand thy meaning, and thou well knowest my practice, I will follow thy counsel. But what will be the end?

sp.speaker: Bom.
sp.p: Thou shalt know before this day end. Farewell.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Now I perceive I must either bewray a mischief, or suffer a continual inconvenience, I must haste homewards, and resolve to make all whole, better a little shame, than an infinite grief, the strangeness will abate the fault, and the bewraying wipe it clean away.
Exit.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Come fellows, it is almost day, let us have a fit of mirth at Sperantus door, and give a Song to the Bride.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: I believe they are asleep , it were pitty to awake them.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: It were a shame they should sleep the first night.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: But who can tell at which house they lie, at Prisius it may be, we will try both.

sp.speaker: Na.
sp.p: Come let us draw like men.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Now, tune, tune I say, that boy, I think, will never profit in his faculty, he looses his Resin, that his Fiddle goes cush, cush, like as one should go wet-shod, and his mouth so dry, that he hath not spittle for his pin as I have .

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: Marry sir you see I go wet-shod and dry mouthed, for yet could I never get new shoes or good drink, rather than I will lead this life, I throw my Fiddle into the Leads for a Hobbler.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Boy, no more words, there is a time for all things, though I say it, that should not, I have been a Minstrel these thirty years, and tickled more strings than thou hast hairs, but yet was never so misused.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Let us not brabble but play, tomorrow is a new day.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: I am sorry I speak in your cast, what shall we sing?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: The Love knot, for that is best for a Bridal. Sing. God morrow fair Bride, and send you joy of your Bridal.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: What a mischief make the twangers here? we have no trenchers to scrape, it makes my teeth on edge to hear such grating. Get you packing, or I will make you wear double stocks, and yet you shall be never the warmer.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: We come for good will, to bid the Bride and Bridegroom God give them joy.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Here is no wedding.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Yes your son and Prisius daughter were married, though you seem strange, yet they repent it not I am sure.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: My son villain, I had rather he were fairly hanged.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: So he is sir, you have your wish.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: Here fiddlers take this, and not a word, hear is no wedding, it was at Memphio's house, yet gramercy, your Music, though it missed the house, hit the mind, we were a-preparing our wedding gear.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: I cry you mercy sir, I think it was Memphios son that was married.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: O ho, the case is altered, go thither then, and be haltered for me.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: what is the alms?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: An Angel.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: I will warrant there is some work towards, ten shillings is money in master Mayors purse.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Let us to Memphios and share equally, when we have done all, thou shalt have new shoes.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: Aye such as they cry at the Assizes, a mark in issues and mark in issues, and yet I never saw so much Leather as would piece one shoes.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: No more, there is the money.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: A good handsel, and I think the Maidenhead of your liberality.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Come here is the house, what shall we sing?

sp.speaker: Lyn.
sp.p: You know Memphio is very rich and wise, and therefore let us strike the gentle stroke, and sing a Catch. sing.

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: The Bride this Night can catch no cold,
No cold, the Bridegroom is young, not old,
Like Ivy he her fast does hold,

sp.speaker: All
sp.l: Then let them alone, They know what they do.
At laugh and lie down, if they play,
What Ass against the sport can bray?
Such Tick-tack has held many a day,

sp.speaker: All 3.
sp.l: Then let them alone, They know what they do,

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: God morrow Mistress Bride, and send you a huddle.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: What crowding Knaves have we there, case up your Fiddles, or the Constable shall cage you up. What Bride talk you of?

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Here is a wedding in Rochester, and it was told me first, that Sperantus son had married Prisius daughter, we were there, and they sent us to your Worship, saying, your son was matched with Stellios daughter.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Hath Sperantus that Churl nothing to do but mock with his Neighbours, I will be even with him, and get you gone, or I swear by the Roods body, I will lay you by the heels.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Sing a catch, here is a fair catch indeed, sing till we catch cold on our feet, and be called knave till our ears glow on our heads, your Worship is wise sir.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Dromio shake off a whole kennel of Officers, to punish these jarring tongues, I will teach them to stretch their dried sheeps guts at my door, and to mock one that stands to be Mayor.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I had thought they had been sticking of Pigs, I heard such a squeaking, I go sir.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: Let us be packing.

sp.speaker: Nas.
sp.p: Where is my scabbard, everyone sheath his science.

sp.speaker: Bed.
sp.p: A bots on the shoemaker that made this boot for my Fiddle, it is too straight.

sp.speaker: Syn.
sp.p: No more words, it will be thought they were the four Waits, and let them wring, as for the Wags that set us on work, we will talk with them.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: They be gone sir.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: If they had stayed, the stocks should have stayed them. But sirrah, what shall we now do?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: As I advised you make a match, for better one house be encumbered with two fools than two.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: It is true, for it being bruited that each of us have a fool, who will tender marriage to any of them that is wise, besides, fools are fortunate, fools are fair, fools are honest.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Aye sir, and more than that, fools are not wise: a wise man is melancholy for Moonshine in the water, careful building Castles in the air, and commonly hath a fool to his heir.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: But what sayst thou to thy Dames chafing?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nothing but all her dishes are chafing-dishes.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: I would her tongue were in thy belly.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: I had as lief have a raw Neats tongue in my stomach.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Marry if the clapper hang within an inch of my heart, that makes mine ears burn a quarter of a mile off. Do you not think it would beat my heart black and blue?

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Well patience is a virtue, but pinching is worse than any vice, I will break this matter to Stellio and if he be willing, this day shall be their wedding.

sp.speaker: Dromio.
sp.p: Then this day shall be my liberty.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Aye if Stellio's Daughter had been wise, and by thy means cozened of a fool.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then sir I will revolt, and dash out the brains of your devices.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Rather thou shalt be free.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Boy, this smoke is token of some fire, I like not the luck of it. Wherefore should these Minstrels dream of a marriage?

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Alas sir, they rustle into every place, give credit to no such words.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: I will to Prisius, I cannot be quiet, and in good time I meet him. God morrow Neighbour.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I cast the morrow in thy fate, and bid good night to all Neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This is your old trick, to pick ones purse, and then to pick quarrels, I tell thee, I had rather thou shouldest rob my chest, than embezzle my son.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Thy son, my daughter is seduced, for I hear say she is married, and our boys can tell. How sayst thou, tell the truth or I will grind thee to powder in my Mill. Be they married?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: True it is they were both in a Church.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: That is no fault, the place is holy.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And there was with them a Priest.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Why what place fitter for a Priest than a Church?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And they took one another by the hand

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Tush, that is but common courtesy.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: And the Priest spake many kind words.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: That showed he was no dumb Minister. But what said they, didst thou hear any words between them?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Faith there was a bargain during life, and the clock cried, God give them joy.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Villain, they be married.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Nay, I think not so.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Yes, yes, God give you joy is a binder, I will quickly be resolved, Candius come forth.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: And I will be put out of doubt. Liuia come forth.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: The Micher hangs down his head.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The baggage begins to blush.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Now begins the game.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I believe it will be no game for us.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Are you married young Master?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: I cannot deny it, it was done so lately.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: But thou shalt repent, it was done so soon.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Then it is bootless to ask you Liuia.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Aye , and needless to be angry.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: It shall pass anger, thou shalt find it rage.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You gave your consent.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Impudent Giglot, was it not enough to abuse me, but also to belie me?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: You sir agreed to this match.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Thou brazen face boy, thinkest thou by learning to persuade me to that which thou speakest. Where did I consent, when, what witness?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: In this place yesterday before Dromio and Risio.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I remember we heard a contract between Memphios son and Stellios daughter, and that our good wills being asked which needed not, we gave them, which booted not.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: It was but the apparel of Accius and Silena, we were the persons.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: O villainy not to be born, Wast thou privy to this practice?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: In a manner.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: I will pay thee after a manner.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And you Oatmeal groat, you were acquainted with this plot.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Accessary as it were.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Thou shalt be punished as principal: here comes Memphio and Stellio they belike were privy, and all their heads were laid together to grieve our hearts.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: Come Stellio, the assurance may be made tomorrow , and our children assured today .

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Let the Conveyance run as we agreed.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: You convey cleanly indeed , if cozenage be clean dealing, for in the apparel of your children you have conveyed a match between ours, which grieves us not a little.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Nay in the apparel of your children, you have discovered the folly of ours, which shames us overmuch.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: But it is no matter, though they be fools they are no beggars.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: And though ours be disobedient, they be no fools.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: So now they tune their pipes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: You shall hear sweet music between a hoarse raven and a screech-owl".

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Neighbours let us not vary, our boys have played their cheating parts. I suspected no less at the Tavern, where our four knaves met together.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: If it were knavery for four to meet in a Tavern, your worship wot well there were other four.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: This villain calls us knaves by craft.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Nay truly, I dare swear he used no craft, but means plainly.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: This is worse, come Halfpenny tell truth and and escape the rod.

sp.speaker: Hal.
sp.p: As good confess here being trust, as at home with my hose about my heels.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Nay I will tell thee, for it will never become thee to utter it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Well out with it.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Memphio had a fool to his son which Stellio knew not, Stellio a fool to his daughter, unknown to Memphio; to cozen each other, they dealt with their boys for a match, we met with Lincio and Halfpenny, who told the love between their masters children, the youth deeply in love, the fathers unwitting to consent.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I will take the tale by the end, then we four met which argued we were no mountains, and in a Tavern we met, which argued we were mortal, and everyone in his wine told his days work, which was a sign we forgot not our business, and seeing all our masters troubled with devices, we determined a little to trouble the water before they drank, so that in the attire of your children, our masters wise children bewrayed their good natures, and in the garments of our masters children yours made a marriage, this all stood upon us poor children, and your young children, to show that old folks may be overtaken by children.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Here is a children indeed, I will never forget it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I will, Accius come forth.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: I forgive all, Silena come forth.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Neighbour, these things cannot be recalled, therefore as good consent, seeing in all our purposes also we missed the mark, for they two will match their children.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Well of that more anon, not so suddenly, least our ungracious youths think we dare do no other, but in truth their loves stirs up nature in me.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come Accius thou must be married to Silena. How art thou minded?

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: What for forever and ever.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: I Accius, what else?

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: I shall never be able to abide it, it will be so tedious.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Silena thou must be betrothed to Accius, and love him for thy husband.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I had as lief have one of clouts.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Why Silena?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Why look how he looks.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: If you will not, another will.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: I thank you for mine old cap.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: And if you be so lusty, lend me two shillings.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: We are happy, we missed the foolish match.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Come, you shall presently be contracted.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Contract their wits no more, they be shrunk close already.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: Well father here is my hand, strike the bargain.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Must he lie with me?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: No Silena, lie by thee.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I shall give her the humble-bees kiss.

sp.speaker: Vici.
sp.p: I forbid the banes.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: What dost thou think them rats, and fearest they shall be poisoned?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: You Vincina, wherefore?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Hearken, about eighteen years ago, I nursed thee a son Memphio, and thee a daughter Stellio.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I had at that time two children of mine own, and being poor, thought it better to change them than kill them, I imagined if by device I could thrust, my children into your houses, they should be well brought up in their youth, and wisely provided for in their age, nature wrought with me, and when they were weaned, I sent home mine instead of yours, which hitherto you have kept tenderly as yours: growing in years I found the children I kept at home to love dearly, at first like brother and sister, which I rejoiced at, but at length too forward in affection, which although inwardly I could not mislike, yet openly I seemed to disallow: they increased in their loving humours, I ceased not to chastise them for their loose demeanours, at last it came to my ears, that my son that was out with Memohio was a fool, that my daughter with Stellio was also unwise, and yet being brother and sister, there was a match in hammering between them.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: What monstrous tale is this?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: And I am sure incredible.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Let her end her discourse.

sp.speaker: Acc.
sp.p: I will never believe it.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: My very bowels earned within me, that I should be author of such vile incest, an hindrance to lawful love, I went to the good old woman Mother Bombie to know the event of this practise, who told me, this day I might prevent the danger, and upon submission escape the punishment, hither I am come to claim my children, though both fools, and to deliver yours both loving.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Is this possible, how shall we believe it?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: It cannot sink into my head.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: This trial cannot fail, your son Memphio had a mole under his ear, I framed one under my childs ear by Art, you shall see it taken away with the juice of mandrake, behold now for your sons, no herb can undo that nature hath done. Your daughter Stellio hath on her wrist a mole, which I counterfeited on my daughters arm, and that shall you see taken away as the other. Thus you see I do not dissemble, hoping you will pardon me, as I have pitied them.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: This is my son. O fortunate Memphio!

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: This is my daughter, more than thrice happy Stellio!

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: How happy is Mstius thou blessed Serena, that being neither children to poor parents, nor brother and sister by nature, may enjoy their love by consent of parents and nature.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Soft, I will not swap my father for all this.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: What do you think I will be cozened of my father, methinks I should not, Mother Bombie told me my father knew me not, my mother bore me not, falsely bred, truly begot, a bots on Mother Bomby.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Mother Bombie told us we should be found cozeners, and in the end be cozened by cozeners, welfare Mother Bomby

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: I heard Mother Bombie say, that thou shalt die a beggar, beware of Mother Bomby

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Why have you all been with Mother Bombie?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: All, and as far as I can see foretold all.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Indeed she is cunning and wise, never doing harm, but still practising good, seeing these things fall out thus, are you content Stellio the match go forward?

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Aye , with double joy, having found for a fool a wise maid, and finding between them both exceeding love.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: Then to end all jars, our children's matches shall stand with our good liking, Liuia enjoy Candius.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Candius enjoy Liuia.

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.p: How shall we recompense fortune, that to our loves hath added our parents good wills?

sp.speaker: Mst.
sp.p: How shall we requite fortune, that to our loves hath added lawfulness, and to our poor estate competent living?

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Vicinia thy fact is pardoned, though the law would see it punished, we be content to keep Silena in the house with the new married couple.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: And I do maintain Accius in our house.

sp.speaker: Vici.
sp.p: Come my children, though fortune hath not provided you lands, yet you see you are not destitute of friends, I shall be eased of a charge both in purse and conscience, in conscience, have revealed my lewd practise, in purse, having you kept of alms.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Come, if you be my sister, it is the better for you.

sp.speaker: Sil.
sp.p: Come brother, methinks it is better than it was, I should have been but a bald bride, I will eat as much pie as if I had been married.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Let us also forgive the knavery of our boys, since all turns to our good haps.

sp.speaker: Stel.
sp.p: Agreed, all are pleased now the boys are unpunished.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: Nay soft, take us with you, and seek redress for our wrongs, or we will complain to the Mayor.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I arrested Memphios boy for an horse after much mocking, at the request of his fellow wags, I was content to take a bond jointly of them all, they had me into a Tavern, there they made me, the Scrivener, and the Sergeant, drunk, pauned his mace for the wine, and sealed me an obligation nothing to the purpose, I pray you read it.

sp.speaker: Memp.
sp.p: What wags be these? Why by this bond you can demand nothing, and things done in drink, may be repented in soberness, but not remedied.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Sir, I have his acquaintance , let him sue his bond.

sp.speaker: Hack.
sp.p: I will cry quittance with thee.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: And I, or it shall cost me the laying on freely of my mace.

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: And I will give thee such a dash with a pen as shall cost thee many a pound, with such a Nouerint as cheap side can show none such.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: Do your worst, our knaveries will revenge it upon your children's children.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Thou boy, we will pay the hire of the horse, be not angry, the boys, have been in a merry cozening vein, for they have served their masters of the same sort, but all must be forgotten, now all are content but the poor fiddlers, they shall be sent for to the marriage and have double fees.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: You need no more send for a fiddler to a feast, than a beggar to a fair.

sp.speaker: St.
sp.p: This day we will feast at my house.

sp.speaker: Mem.
sp.p: Tomorrow at mine.

sp.speaker: Pri.
sp.p: The next day at mine.

sp.speaker: Spe.
sp.p: Then at mine the last day, and even so spend this week in good cheer.

sp.speaker: Dro.
sp.p: Then we were best be going whilst everyone is pleased, and yet these couples are not fully pleased, till the priest have done his worst.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Come Sergeant we will toss it this week, and make thy mace arrest a boiled capon.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: No more words at the wedding, if the Mayor should know it, I were in danger of mine office.

sp.speaker: Ri.
sp.p: Then take heed how on such as we are, you show a cast of your office.

sp.speaker: Half.
sp.p: If you mace us, we will pepper you.

sp.speaker: Ac.
sp.p: Come sister, the best is, we shall have good cheer these four days.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: And be fools forever .

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: That is none of our upseekings.
